before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"7fu4q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"djbtk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"esf2d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aaqak","text":"It is essential to wear disposable plastic gloves during all laboratory procedures and to use pipette tips that are sterile and fitted with filters.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"5486r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1c028","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1rgem","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"akbgu","text":"BACKGROUND","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"s5k4","text":"World-wide trade with plant material has dramatically increased over the past decades, and with it has  the risk for accidental introduction of potential plant pests and diseases. Rapid and accurate nucleic acid based identification of such quarantine organisms has become an important tool to minimize their  dispersal. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rber","text":"Nucleic acid based identification exploits genetic diversity. A basic tenet holds that species generally do not interbreed and hence, the level of genetic differentiation within species is generally lower than between species. For insects, this pattern of genetic diversity is being used by DNA barcoding with  great success. An approximately 600 base pairs long fragment in the first half of the mitochondrially encoded cytochrome c oxidase I gene (COI) is used as a reference sequence to identify insects at the species level. So far, reference sequences for ca. 231’000 different insect species are deposited on the publicly available “Barcoding for Life Database” BOLD (http://www.barcodinglife.org/; by June 2021). Another important database especially targeting phytosanitary purposes with DNA barcodes of vouchered reference specimen is the EPPO Q-Bank (European Plant Protection Organization, https://qbank.eppo.int/). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":674,"length":29},{"key":2,"offset":901,"length":23}],"data":{}},{"key":"5rrto","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1uusr","text":"The methodology of DNA barcoding generally relies on PCR amplification of the diagnostic COI gene fragment using a pair of primers for which the exact DNA sequence must be known. However, this information is not always available, for example in the case of so far undescribed species or in cases, where genetic variation within species affected primer sites. Furthermore, although the COI marker sequence shows an impressive degree of among species differentiation, this is not true for all species and hence, a number of important pest species cannot be differentiated based on this marker alone. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ci49","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4bpuf","text":"An ideal method for species identification should therefore obtain information of the best discriminating genetic region or of several genetic regions. Here, we describe a state-of-the-art method to achieve  this task.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"58b3v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c0os","text":"PURPOSE","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3jsh7","text":"The purpose of this workflow is to provide a generic method for genetic identification of potential insect quarantine species and of other especially dangerous pest species in support of the Swiss Federal Plant Protection Service. The method is marker independent and may be used with reference databases of any genetic fragment. It is based on whole genome amplification, followed by single strand nanopore sequencing and DNA barcoding based identification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2i6qm","text":"This protocol uses proteinase K containing KAWA buffer for DNA extraction.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"brkm","text":"An alternative version that uses Monarch® Genomic DNA Purification Kit for DNA extraction and purification can be found here:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"31b83","text":" guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"9h4nj","text":"SCOPE","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ch53","text":"This method is suitable for the qualitative identification of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) or cDNA (reverse-transcribed DNA of RNA of, e.g., viruses) of potentially all organisms. It has been tested against a broad taxonomic range of pest species. The workflow is designed to work with fresh, ethanol (EtOH; preferably 70%) preserved and frozen samples. The workflow presented here is established for insect species identification, but it was successfully applied to the identification of fungi and bacteria using the proper reference databases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"15dk3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dk9o3","text":"DEFINITIONS \u0026 ABBREVIATION","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c0qhd","text":"DNA: Deoxyribonucleic acid  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cliou","text":"PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ftlai","text":"SOP: Standard Operating Procedure  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4hhk8","text":"UV: Ultraviolet  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1t0fk","text":"WGA: Whole Genome Amplification ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"499o","text":"CO1/COI: Mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase 1 gene ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":23,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b84fq","text":"Bp: Base pairs","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9tjov","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"afeje","text":"PRINCIPLE OF THE METHOD","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62hv4","text":"The workflow starts with nucleic acid extraction (DNA and/or RNA followed by cDNA production), followed by a WGA step of the extracted DNA/cDNA, then a clean-up step before producing the nanopore sequencing library which finally is loaded on the MinION nanopore sequencing device. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ebtv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbe1r","text":"The methods chosen for this workflow aim at flexibility of input material (gDNA, cDNA) and optimal output to enable multiple use of single flowcells. The workflow should in principle enable at least 10 individual runs of ca. 2-4 hours data collection on a single MinION flowcell. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45p3m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"atj7d","text":"The resulting sequence data, ideally \u003e 200’000 reads per individual sample, are loaded into the software ‘Geneious Prime’ and analyzed by a custom-made workflow using the proper reference library (see section \"Materials\"). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"67li8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bfotu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"flr3q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ter3","text":"7 Raw Data Processing and Analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5gbs5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6n7vj","text":"7.1 Primary Data Acquisition and Basecalling","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":44}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvnld","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ffdj2","text":"Primary data acquisition is performed with the Oxford Nanopore Technologies (ONT) data acquisition software MinKNOW GUI v.4.2.8, the operating software that drives nanopore sequencing devices. Basecalling of the raw nanopore sequencing read data is required to generate the fastq sequence data files needed for further analysis. Basecalling is a time-consuming process and hence it is beneficial to use graphic processing units (GPU) to support this process. To enable use of GPU for basecalling generally requires access to a Linux based operating system with decent memory and storage capacity. We use a Dell Precision 7920 Tower XCTO Base with 256GB RAM and a Nvidia Quadro RTX6000, 24 GB graphic card running Ubuntu 18.04. We use the software Guppy v. 4.5.4 for basecalling using GPU with a parameter set established by Miles Benton (https://gist.github.com/sirselim/2ebe2807112fae93809aa18f096dbb94#file-basecalling_notes-md) to be used from a terminal window: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":838,"length":91}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ercg","text":"/guppy_basecaller --disable_pings --input_path /{location_of_data_folder}/ --save_path /{location_of_save_data_folder}/ -c dna_r9.4.1_450bps_hac.cfg -x 'auto' --recursive --num_callers 4 -- gpu_runners_per_device 8 --chunks_per_runner 1024 --chunk_size 1000 ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vb76","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"68q0c","text":"The process generates fastq data files and places all reads with a minimum quality into a folder named “passed”.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gu4u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"uugl","text":"7.2 Data analysis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k0c4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8tus5","text":"To store and analyze the basecalled fastq nanopore read sequences obtained by sequencers from Oxford Nanopore Technologies (MinION, PromethION, GridION, Flongle) we use the software Geneious Prime v.21.1.1 or greater.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3p5pa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3p8ns","text":"We developed an automated workflow that combines several steps including mapping reads to a reference database (in our case containing ca. 600 base pairs 5’ of the mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase I gene of insects, downloaded from the ‘Barcoding of Life Database’ BOLD), establishing a consensus sequence and running a BLAST search on a local copy of the GenBank database. The BLAST results which generally enable species identification of the sample are stored in a sub-folder.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"991k5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cn6vs","text":"Open the Geneious Prime software by clicking on the corresponding icon ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"780r4","text":"In the left panel, go to your working folder and right-click to generate a new folder for storage and analysis of your new nanopore data files. We recommend to use a new folder for each run and within that folder a sub-folder for each barcoded sample. The nanopore fastq data files are stored in a folder on the computer system running the software ‘MinKNOW’ (which enables performing nanopore sequencing on the MinION as mentioned above) with a name similar to ‘passed’ and have the extension ‘.fastq’. For each barcoded sample, the corresponding fastq files have to be copied into the newly established data sub-folder in Geneious, for example, via drag and drop. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82oso","text":"Select the desired number of read packets (by default, 4000 reads per packet), ideally ca. 200’000 in total, by activating them in the right-hand window, then select “Workflows – LB_MM2_PcRefSeq_NrSeq_ret30_210212” from the Geneious Prime menu. If that workflow (incl. in Appendix) does not appear on the menu you have to import it first. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"295l1","text":"In the new pop-up window, select the proper reference database – default is the custom made 59k entry database (RefDB_BOLD59kGBCocc755_60625Seq_211213.fasta; incl. in Appendix) extracted from BOLD and modified to exclude duplicates and to maintain a 97% minimal distance between branches. Upon confirming with ‘ok’ the workflow will perform the following steps using the parameters indicated below: ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"erg6f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8tbll","text":"    a) Mapper: Minimap2 v.2.17 with the following parameters: Dissolve contigs and re-assemble selected; reference     sequence: RefDB_BOLD59kGBCocc755_60625Seq_211213; data type: Oxford Nanopore; include secondary alignments: maximum secondary aligments per read: 5; minimum secondary to primary alignment score ratio: 0.8; no trimming (remove existing trim regions from sequences); and under advanced options, an additional command line option: -t 8. Also, in the results panel, select ‘Save assemply report’, ‘Save in sub-folder’ and ‘Save contigs’.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qeut","text":"     b) Sort Documents: Field to sort by: % of Ref Seq; select ‘Reverse Sort’ and ‘After sorting, only keep at most 30 documents.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"674p6","text":"    c) Mask Alignment: Eliminates alignment columns with \u003c35% entries; in the Options panel, select ‘Expose no options; in the Results panel, select ‘Save a copy with sites stripped; in the What to mask or strip panel, select ‘Sites containing: Gaps (%) 35%; in the All Operation Options panel, select ‘Don’t append ‘Stripped’ to sequence names. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36vg7","text":"    d) Save Documents: Select ‘Save these documents as output from workflow’, ‘Save in subfolder called: {Folder Name}; ‘Select these documents when the operation completes, and ‘Continue’. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"342m8","text":"    e) Generate Consensus Sequence: Establishes a consensus sequence with a 0% majority threshold. Uses the following parameters: In the Options panel, select ‘Expose no options; in the All Operation Options panel, select ‘Threshold: 0% - Majority’, ‘Ignore Gaps’, ‘Assign Quality Total’, ‘Trim to reference sequence’, and ‘Append text to name of alignment consensus sequence’. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3aus1","text":"    f) Save Documents: Select ‘Save these documents as output from workflow’, ‘Save in subfolder called: {Folder Name}; ‘Select these documents when the operation completes, and ‘Continue’.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3bep","text":"    g) BLAST: Performs a BLAST search for the ‘contig consensus sequence ‘ on a local GenBank database copy using the program ‘Megablast’, places results into a ‘Hit table’, retrieving ‘Matching regions with annotations’, and saves the top 10 best hits in a new folder. Uses the following parameters: In the Options panel, select ‘Expose no options; in the All Operation Options panel, select ‘Nucleotide Query Option’, Database ‘Nucleotide collection (nr/nt), Program: ‘Megablast’, Results: ‘Hit table’, Retrieve ‘Matching region with annotations’, Macimum Hits ‘10’. Also selected is ‘Low Complexity Filter’ and ‘Mask for lookup table’, with other parameters being default values. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4bmi0","text":"    h) Save Documents: Select ‘Save these documents as output from workflow’, ‘Save in subfolder called: {Folder Name}; and ‘Branch from 2 Operations Ago’. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36inm","text":"    i) Sort Documents: In the Options panel, select ‘Expose no options; In the Options panel, select Field to sort by: ‘Bit-Score’, and select ‘After sorting, only keep at most 30 documents.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7etvg","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6dl4f","text":"The BLAST results in the new folder are sorted according to the highest Bit-Score for the hit which in most cases will present the highest % Pairwise Identity and the lowest probability value (E-Value) on top of the list. In addition, Geneious Prime adds other information for proper qualification of the BLAST hits. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3kbr","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aoar3","text":"Generally, the results obtained with this workflow provide ‘% Pairwise Identity’ hits of \u003e99% and hence strong evidence for an unambiguous species identification of the sample for which the consensus sequence was established.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":89,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"684pp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h9hj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8nmre","text":"7.3 Additional Resources","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7h1j0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehgbq","text":"Geneious Prime: Training videos and other resources for all steps outlined above for the software Geneious Prime are available on the Geneious homepage: Resources | Geneious Prime ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":153,"length":26}],"data":{}},{"key":"6ne07","text":"Barcoding of Life Database: The Barcode of life systems page (http://www.boldsystems.org/) is an excellent resource for barcoding based identifications and it allows searching their database with the proper marker sequence (e.g., COI for insects and ITS for fungi; see detailed instructions below).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":62,"length":27}],"data":{}},{"key":"1dcj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"61d0i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2rmr7","text":"8 Barcode-based identification on the NCBI GenBank Database ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d9i5b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52g6n","text":"As an alternative to the identification using local BLAST implemented in the Geneious Prime workflow, the consensus sequence may also be BLASTed directly on the GenBank Database of NCBI:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"rpmt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cnh9f","text":"Open the BLAST homepage of NCBI (https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi) and choose the web BLAST option ‘Nucleotide BLAST’. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":33,"length":40}],"data":{}},{"key":"dll2s","text":"Paste your consensus sequence into the window ‘Enter Query Sequence’ ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8tnf","text":"Check that the following parameters are chosen: a. Under ‘Choose Search Set’, ‘Database’: Choose ‘Standard’, and ‘Nucleotide collection (nr/nt)’ in the dropdown menu; leave the other fields empty. b. Under ‘Program selection’, ‘Optimize for’: Choose ‘Highly similar sequences (megablast) c. Select ‘Show results in a new window’ before you select ‘BLAST’ at the bottom left of the web page d. It may take a short while before GenBank returns the BLAST results in a new window: ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":197,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":288,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":390,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bsi34","text":"Criteria for correct species allocation are, among others: a. The top \u003e10 entries are the same species name, however, there may be synonymous names for many insects. b. The identity of the query sequence with the GenBank entry (column ‘Ident’) is \u003e97% c. The coverage region of the alignment between your consensus sequence and the GenBank entry is \u003e80% (at least 300bp) d. The E-Value is very close to 0","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":59,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":166,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":252,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":371,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddadf","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7lp9r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ch61o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"95kir","text":"9 Barcode-based identification on the Barcode of Life Database","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avajh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"deb1q","text":"In order to identify what species your consensus, full-length COI sequence originates from it is necessary to utilize reference databases. One example for such reference database is the Barcode of Life Database (BOLD). This database includes a comprehensive set of COI sequence data that has been collected by individuals and organizations across the globe and is constantly being updated with new data. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3665","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fapk6","text":"Start by navigating to the BOLD Systems webpage (http://www.boldsystems.org/) and select the “Identification” tab at the top of the webpage. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":5,"offset":49,"length":27}],"data":{}},{"key":"fl801","text":"Using the default settings, select the “Animal Identification (COI)” tab (for arthropod identification) and the “Species Level Barcode Records” database. Paste the consensus sequence obtained from the sample into the search box at the bottom of the page. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"50cha","text":"The browser will eventually update and return the results of the search, revealing the records contained in the database that yield the closest match in terms of sequence similarity. The result screen contains a lot of information that may be explored to establish a confident identification for the query sequence. Often the search results will all originate from a single species allowing an unambiguous identification to be made for the sample. In some cases, two or more species are returned, prompting BOLD to display the message “A species match could not be made, the queried specimen is likely to be one of the following”. This may, for example, happen when highly similar reference sequences were entered with different names (synonyms) for the same species.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"662f5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ujbv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fg8i3","text":"10 Barcode-based identification on the EPPO-Q-Bank Database ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":60}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74iq9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bh25","text":"Open the EPPO-Q-Bank homepage (https://qbank.eppo.int/blast?db=arthropods), check that ‘Arthropods’ are selected and paste your consensus sequence into the window ‘Paste sequence to align:’ and select ‘Start alignment’ ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":6,"offset":31,"length":42}],"data":{}},{"key":"a3bag","text":"EPPO-Q-Bank will return its results in the lower part of the same window: ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ebcr3","text":"The percent identity of your query sequence to the best match entries in the EPPO-Q-Bank Database is indicated in the column ‘Similarity %’, the percent overlap of both sequences in the column ‘Overlap %’. If both values are close to 100% then the species allocation is reliable.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bq5m","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":7,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8r9hi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"418A1530EBF711EB81648B95DE7BB72B","url":"https://gist.github.com/sirselim/2ebe2807112fae93809aa18f096dbb94#file-basecalling_notes-md"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B9FDA770EBF711EB81648B95DE7BB72B","url":"https://www.geneious.com/resources/"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"C4595390EBF711EB81648B95DE7BB72B","url":"http://www.boldsystems.org/"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"5F14FD80EBF811EB81648B95DE7BB72B","url":"https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi"}},"4":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c1krf","text":"Note: GenBank does contain erroneous entries that may, for example, originate from an error in allocating the sample to the correct species based on morphological characters. Such cases can be identified easily if there is only a single such entry in a long list of identical species names.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"5":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"4110D880F76611EBB33593F036E29182","url":"http://www.boldsystems.org/"}},"6":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8FDA5780EBF811EB81648B95DE7BB72B","url":"https://qbank.eppo.int/blast?db=arthropods"}},"7":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7bojp","text":"Note: The three databases mentioned above are basically independent, although there is much overlap between GenBank and BOLD. This means that not all species are represented in all databases but rather in only one or two of them. Furthermore, the set of individual references for a species is mostly different in each database. Therefore, BLAST results will generally be different among the databases.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}
